newsitem.title: USA: USDA proposes changes to conservation programs.
newsitem.headline: USDA proposes changes to conservation programs.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Friday proposed changes to the wetland conservation or swampbuster program and the conservation compliance program aimed at minimizing regulatory burdens for farmers.
The changes include items required by the 1996 Farm Bill.

Among the proposals, which were published in the Federal Register with a 60-day comment period, USDA seeks to ensure penalties for violations of the programs "be fair and reasonable and reflect the seriousness of the violation."
It said it would keep certified wetland delineations in effect until a producer requested a new one.
USDA also said it proposes to provide greater flexibility to mitigate the loss of wetland functions and values through restoration, enhancement or creation of wetlands.

It said it would establish a process to identify practices that have a minimal effect on wetlands, revise the concept of "abandonment" and assure that producers can ask for technical help without fear of being found in violation of compliance.
"These changes are built on a foundation of local participation, flexibility, good science and common sense," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said in a statement.
"They will make our conservation programs more equitable and flexible without compromising environmental protection," he said.
